Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task sits on the critical path for an external delivery promised to a client.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I glance at my watch, anxiety prickling at my skin. The client’s delivery is tomorrow, and my part of the project is the last piece holding everything together. My team is counting on me to finish by the end of the day, and I promised I would. But here I am, standing in a long line at the polling station, laptop in my bag, trying to do my civic duty. Suddenly, an official calls out, “Voters with last names A through M, please move to the new line on the left!” My last name starts with B. The new line is barely moving, while the original one is finally picking up speed. I know the rules: follow the officials’ instructions. But every minute I spend here is a minute lost for my team, and the deadline is looming. My phone buzzes with a message from my manager: “Any update?” I feel torn—do I obey the official and risk missing my deadline, or do I stay put and risk causing trouble at the polling station? My heart pounds as I weigh my responsibilities, caught between being a good colleague and a responsible voter.
